member.name: T:Ridder.UnitsOfMeasurement.Bases.ConversionFactorQuantityBase`1
member.summary: Base class for all quantities that use a conversion factor to convert from and to standard unit.
member.typeparam: The unit enum type for this quantity.

member.name: M:Ridder.UnitsOfMeasurement.Bases.ConversionFactorQuantityBase`1.#ctor(Ridder.UnitsOfMeasurement.Enums.QuantityType,`0)
member.summary: Initializes a new object for this type.
member.param: The quantity enum value for this quantity.
The unit enum value for the standard unit of this quantity.

member.name: M:Ridder.UnitsOfMeasurement.Bases.ConversionFactorQuantityBase`1.GetConversionFactors
member.summary: Used to retrieve the conversion factors for this quantity. This method is called once during the objects lifetime, when the units are requested for the first time.
member.returns: The conversion factors for this quantity.

member.name: F:Ridder.UnitsOfMeasurement.Enums.QuantityType.Scalar
member.summary: Used for values that have no quantity.

member.name: T:Ridder.UnitsOfMeasurement.Interfaces.IUnit
member.summary: Interface for defining units.

member.name: P:Ridder.UnitsOfMeasurement.Interfaces.IUnit.Identifier
member.summary: The unit identifier. Can be used to retrieve a unit object using the method on the static class. The main purpose of this identifier is serialization over application boundries.

member.name: M:Ridder.UnitsOfMeasurement.Interfaces.IUnit.GetQuantity
member.summary: Retrieves the quantity of this unit.

member.name: M:Ridder.UnitsOfMeasurement.Interfaces.IUnit.FromStandardUnit(System.Double,System.DateTimeOffset)
member.summary: Converts the given value from the standard unit of this quantity into this unit.
member.param: The value that should be converted.
The timestamp when this value was recorded. Mainly used by time-dependent conversions like Currency.
member.returns: The value converted to this unit.

member.name: M:Ridder.UnitsOfMeasurement.Interfaces.IUnit.ToStandardUnit(System.Double,System.DateTimeOffset)
member.summary: Converts the given value from this unit to standard unit.
member.param: The value that should be converted.
The timestamp when this value was recorded. Mainly used by time-dependent conversions like Currency.
member.returns: The value converted to the standard unit of this quantity.

member.name: M:Ridder.UnitsOfMeasurement.Interfaces.IUnit.GetSymbol(System.Globalization.CultureInfo)
member.summary: Retrieves the symbol that corresponds to this unit. Can be used to display this value with the correct symbol.
member.param: The cultureInfo that should be used to determine the correct symbol.
member.returns: The symbol that corresponds to this unit and the given CultureInfo.

member.name: M:Ridder.UnitsOfMeasurement.Interfaces.IUnit.GetFormattedValue(System.Double,System.Globalization.CultureInfo)
member.summary: Formats the given value into a string with the correct symbol. Can be used to display the value as a string with the correct symbol and correct symbol placement.
member.param: The value that should be formatted
The CultureInfo that should be used to determine the correct formatting.
member.returns: The value formatted with the correct symbol and correct symbol placement for the given Culture Info

member.name: T:Ridder.UnitsOfMeasurement.Interfaces.IUnit`1
member.summary: Interface for defining units of a certain enum type.
member.typeparam: The enum type of the unit.

member.name: P:Ridder.UnitsOfMeasurement.Interfaces.IUnit`1.Type
member.summary: The enum type of the unit.

member.name: M:Ridder.UnitsOfMeasurement.Interfaces.IUnit`1.GetQuantity
member.summary: Retrieves the typed quantity for this unit.
member.returns: The typed quantity for this unit.

member.name: T:Ridder.UnitsOfMeasurement.Quantities.AngleQuantity
member.summary: In plane geometry, an angle is the figure formed by two rays, called the sides of the angle, sharing a common endpoint, called the vertex of the angle.

member.name: T:Ridder.UnitsOfMeasurement.Quantities.AreaQuantity
member.summary: In geometry, the area can be defined as the space occupied by a flat shape or the surface of an object. The area of a figure is the number of unit squares that cover the surface of a closed figure. Area is measured in square units such as square centimteres, square feet, square inches, etc.

member.name: T:Ridder.UnitsOfMeasurement.Quantities.CurrencyQuantity
member.summary: Currency is a medium of exchange for goods and services. In short, it's money, in the form of paper or coins, usually issued by a government and generally accepted at its face value as a method of payment.

member.name: T:Ridder.UnitsOfMeasurement.Quantities.DistanceQuantity
member.summary: Distance is a numerical measurement of how far apart objects or points are. In physics or everyday usage, distance may refer to a physical length or an estimation based on other criteria (e.g. "two counties over"). In the SI system, it is specified in units of m (meters).

member.name: T:Ridder.UnitsOfMeasurement.Quantities.DurationQuantity
member.summary: The amount of elapsed time between two events. In the SI system, it is specified in units of s (seconds).

member.name: T:Ridder.UnitsOfMeasurement.Quantities.ElectricConductanceQuantity
member.summary: In electronics and electromagnetism, electronical conducance is the reciproclal quantity of electric resistance. In the SI system, it is specified in units S (Siemens). The resistance, and thus conductance of an object depends in large part on the material it is made of.

member.name: T:Ridder.UnitsOfMeasurement.Quantities.EnergyQuantity
member.summary: In physics, energy is the quantitative property that must be transferred to an object in order to perform work on, or to heat, the object. Energy is a conserved quantity; the law of conservation of energy states that energy can be converted in form, but not created or destroyed. The SI unit of energy is the joule, which is the energy transferred to an object by the work of moving it a distance of 1 metre against a force of 1 newton.

member.name: T:Ridder.UnitsOfMeasurement.Quantities.MassQuantity
member.summary:
Mass is both a property of a physical body and a measure of its resistance to acceleration (a change in its state of motion) when a net force is applied. An object's mass also determines the strength of its gravitational attraction to other bodies. The basic SI unit of mass is the kilogram (kg).
In physics, mass is not the same as weight, even though mass is often determined by measuring the object's weight using a spring scale, rather than balance scale comparing it directly with known masses. An object on the Moon would weigh less than it does on Earth because of the lower gravity, but it would still have the same mass. This is because weight is a force, while mass is the property that (along with gravity) determines the strength of this force.

member.name: T:Ridder.UnitsOfMeasurement.Quantities.PHQuantity
member.summary: Defines the pH quantity

member.name: T:Ridder.UnitsOfMeasurement.Quantities.PowerQuantity
member.summary: In physics, power is the amount of energy transferred or converted per unit time. In the SI system, the unit of power is the watt, equal to one joule per second.

member.name: T:Ridder.UnitsOfMeasurement.Quantities.PressureQuantity
member.summary: Pressure units class

member.name: T:Ridder.UnitsOfMeasurement.Quantities.Products.EcVolumeQuantity
member.summary: ECVolume is an approximation of the amount of fertilizer distributed in a body of water. It is calculated by multiplying the average EC value of the irrigation cycle by the amount of water given in the irrigation cycle.

member.name: T:Ridder.UnitsOfMeasurement.Quantities.Rates.ElectricConductivityQuantity
member.summary: Electrical conductivity is the measure of a material's ability to allow the transport of an electric charge. Its SI is the siemens per meter, (A2s3m−3kg−1) (named after Werner von Siemens) or, more simply, Sm−1. It is the ratio of the current density to the electric field strength.

member.name: T:Ridder.UnitsOfMeasurement.Quantities.Rates.IrradianceQuantity
member.summary: Irradiance (or flux density) is a term of radiometry and is defined as the radiant flux received by some surface per unit area. In the SI system, it is specified in units of W/m2 (watts per square meter). Irradiance may be applied to light or other kinds of radiation.

member.name: T:Ridder.UnitsOfMeasurement.Quantities.Rates.VelocityQuantity
member.summary: The velocity of an object is the rate of change of its position with respect to a frame of reference, and is a function of time. In the SI system, it is specified in units of m/s (meters per second). Velocity is equivalent to a specification of an object's speed and direction of motion (e.g. 60 km/h to the north).

member.name: T:Ridder.UnitsOfMeasurement.Quantities.RatioQuantity
member.summary: In mathematics, a ratio indicates how many times one number contains another.

member.name: T:Ridder.UnitsOfMeasurement.Quantities.ScalarQuantity
member.summary: Used for values that do not have a unit, like count.

member.name: T:Ridder.UnitsOfMeasurement.Quantities.TemperatureQuantity
member.summary: Temperature is a physical quantity that expresses hot and cold. It is the manifestation of thermal energy, present in all matter, which is the source of the occurrence of heat, a flow of energy, when a body is in contact with another that is colder.

member.name: T:Ridder.UnitsOfMeasurement.Quantities.VolumeQuantity
member.summary: Volume is the quantity of three-dimensional space enclosed by a closed surface, for example, the space that a substance (solid, liquid, gas, or plasma) or shape occupies or contains. Volume is often quantified numerically using the SI derived unit, the cubic metre.

member.name: T:Ridder.UnitsOfMeasurement.Resources.UnitsFormatting.UnitsFormatting
member.summary: A strongly-typed resource class, for looking up localized strings, etc.

member.name: P:Ridder.UnitsOfMeasurement.Resources.UnitsFormatting.UnitsFormatting.ResourceManager

member.name: P:Ridder.UnitsOfMeasurement.Resources.UnitsFormatting.UnitsFormatting.Culture
member.summary: Overrides the current thread's CurrentUICulture property for all resource lookups using this strongly typed resource class.
